Date: Thu, 5 Oct 2023 15:07:36 +0000
Good Afternoon

There seems to be some confusion on point 4 on your original email.

4) Richard from Trinity Rose has asked for confirmation that his costs will be covered for the time spent dealing with Adrian Sims, at a cost of £1500.This has not been agreed or part of the memorandum of agreement.

For plot 34 survey and report, for £2,500.  I understand that this was supposed to have been a joint engagement with Trinity, but Richard has confirmed that he has not had any contact from Crest. I have not been informed by Trinity what the cost for the second visit, if needed, would be. I can confirm we will pay Trinity Rose directly upon receipt of invoice via BACs.

As per the agreement 2.2.4 We confirm we will pay you £1300 (Trinity Rose report)

The stage 12 is Monday once carpets have been fitted. Please confirm Trinity Rose is booked for the 11th.

We require the redemption statement, which is valid for 30 days and evidence of must be fulfilled before we can offer a fixed date.

I will come back to you regarding the personal door in the garage.

Kind Regards

Good morning Serhan,

I have copied the email, below, that we will be sending to all members of
Crest who were sent the email from Natalie Haigh that was later retracted.

Our mortgage advisor has informed us that the rates have gone up, meaning
our borrowing ability has dropped by approximately £6k.  We could not have
made it any clearer to Mr Sims and Peter Truscott (CEO) that the delays are
jeopardising everything, and said this multiple times.  Please could you
advise? We realistically need them to change the purchasing price to
reflect this, and be aware that this could change again at any time.

Regards,
Paul


Good morning Natalie,

Thank you for requesting a retraction over the weekend of the email sent
after our meeting on Albany Road on Friday. I'm grateful that you said that
you could understand why we would be disappointed, and that is why you
worded it in that way. The offer for a meal was a kind gesture, but not
necessary.


Since the email was still sent, I would be grateful if you could confirm
for us, to all adressees, that the content of it could have been worded in
a way which did not paint my husband in a negative light, however well
intentioned it was.

I believe that since you and Steve have not been made fully aware of the
situation, it is not possible for you to understand the frustration we
continue to have with the way we are being treated by Crest. Mr Sims stated
in his email of 1st June that there needs to not be multiple lines of
communication, however unless everyone is aware of all facts, this can not
happen.  Going forwards, it is essential that Crest communicates correctly
within the organisation.

I will answer each of the points:

-- They advised we have wasted their time as they believed the property
would be pre plastered, they wanted to check this today, as this is the
main issue in their current property.

Our time is not being used productively. Not only do we still have to chase
at

Subject: Re: Plot 34 Crest
From: Paul Taylor <paulroberttaylor@gmail.com>
To: Serhan Handani <sh@bramsdonandchilds.com>
Date: Wed, 7 Jun 2023 09:42:58 +0100
Good morning Serhan,

While it's great news that they are agreeing to do the exchange after the
property has been checked, the fact that we have reduced borrowing and
increased monthly payments because of Mr Sims will mean that they are
making the entire transaction untenable, to the point where it may be
necessary to go ahead and do the work, losing their non-disclosure
agreement.

They need to be reasonable, since their actions, or lack thereof, is what
has put us in this position.  We can not take out a mortgage based on the
current borrowing and interest rates unless they are willing to cover the
difference, which in the bigger picture is pennies to them.

documents:
Subject: Re: 25 Abbots Road - Crest Nicholson property buy back
From: Serhan Handani <sh@bramsdonandchilds.com>
To: Paul Taylor <paulroberttaylor@gmail.com>, Jade Taylor
	<jade.millington@hotmail.co.uk>
Date: Tue, 11 Apr 2023 13:17:43 +0000
Good afternoon Paul,

Thank you. I have reviewed the revised version. I shall address your points first.

With respect to 2.2.5 - I am unsure what you mean by full valuation. This covers the fee your mortgage lender will charge you for valuation of the property. It is not a valuation that you would undertake but one by your mortgage lender to agree the lending. I have no concerns with the wording here.

Clause 7.1 - I do not believe your suggested wording is necessary. I cannot see that your suggestion would be to your advantage as it would be better to have their commitment to meet the costs as set out in clause 2, irrespective of what property you end up purchasing.

Clause 8 - I have no concerns with their wording here. It would be wholly unusual for confidentiality to expire, that would defy the point of the clause. You are not bound to this agreement if Crest commits a material breach of the agreement, it would not be usual to include a clause to that effect, but you can request.

The confidentiality clause will not take effect if the buyback does not, for the reasons set out above.

I agree the clause only protects Crest, but that is the purpose of the clause and is their consideration in offering this settlement. They would be unwilling to settle this dispute without the confidentiality and have made that clear.

As you should have no reason to need to disclose this agreement, save if you need to litigate to enforce the agreement (which you are not prevented from doing), I would advise accepting the wording.

The remaining matters appear to be terms you have yet to agree with Crest. I cannot offer you legal advice on what the terms of the settlement should be but if you wish to include the garage doors, you should negotiate to include this. They are, of course, not obligated to include them.

Any incurred costs are your liability initially, not Crest. Technically you must settle all your own costs and be reimbursed by Crest. In reality, they
